com.github.parboiled1.grappa.event
Class EventBusParser<V>

java.lang.Object
  org.parboiled.BaseActions<V>
      org.parboiled.BaseParser<V>
          com.github.parboiled1.grappa.event.EventBusParser<V>
Type Parameters:
V - the result type of the parser
All Implemented Interfaces:
ContextAware<V>
@Experimental
public abstract class EventBusParser<V>
extends BaseParser<V>

A basic parser with an attached EventBus

This parser allows you to register events and listeners.

Events are registered by a unique name (which must not be null), using the addEvent(String, Class) method; the class passed as an argument must have a constructor accepting a Context as an argument; grappa provides one such class, BasicMatchEvent, which grabs the match of the current context (see Context.getMatch()).

Note that the addEvent() method is both protected and final; the recommended use is to add events in the constructor; for instance:

     public class MyParser
         extends EventBusParser<Object>
     {
         MyParser()
         {
             addEvent("basicEvent", BasicMatchEvent.class);
             addEvent("myEvent", MyEvent.class);
         }
     }

Listeners are classes of yours; methods which will listen on events need to be annotated with Subscribe; they must also be public and accept only one argument, which is the event class. For instance:

     public final class MyListener
     {
         private String match;

         (Subscribe
         public void receiveMatch(final BasicMatchEvent event)
         {
             match = event.getMatch();
         }
     }

You then register instances of your listeners on your generated parser using the addListener(Object) method:

     final MyParser parser = Parboiled.createParser(MyParser.class);
     final MyListener listener = new MyListener();
     parser.addListener(listener);

In order to get events to be published in the parsing process, you will use the fireEvent(String) method; the argument to this method must be a name you have registered using addEvent(). Given the above, you will therefore write, for instance:

     Rule wantToCaptureThat()
     {
         return sequence(string("Capture me!"), fireEvent("basicEvent"));
     }

This will cause the parser to create a new instance of the class associated with this name with the current parser context as a constructor argument, which it will then publish via the event bus.

Note that you are not limited to one subscriber per event class. For the full details of how, and when, events are dispatched, see the javadoc for {@code EventBus}.

See Also:
EventBus, BasicMatchEvent

Method Detail

addEvent

protected final void addEvent(@Nonnull
                              String eventName,
                              @Nonnull
                              Class<?> eventClass)
Associate an event class to a given name

Note that at this moment, if you register an event twice with the same name, the previous event class is overriden without notice.

Note also that grappa makes no effort to modify the visibility of constructors, nor does it check it; it is therefore your responsibility to ensure that both the class and constructor have sufficient "access privileges".

Parameters:
eventName - the name to associate this event to
eventClass - the event class
Throws:
GrappaException - no suitable constructor found
See Also:
BasicMatchEvent, fireEvent(String)

addListener

public final void addListener(@Nonnull
                              Object listener)
Register a listener to the event bus

Parameters:
listener - the listener
See Also:
EventBus.register(Object)

fireEvent

public boolean fireEvent(@Nonnull
                         String eventName)
Fire an event by name

See the class description for more details.

Parameters:
eventName - the name of the event
Returns:
always true
See Also:
ActionMatcher, Action
